segments.en: Middle Discourses 63
The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkya
So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmato mālukyaputtassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
segments.en: Then as Venerable Māluṅkya was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:
“There are several convictions that the Buddha has left undeclared; he has set them aside and refused to comment on them.

segments.pli: ‘sassato loko’tipi, ‘asassato loko’tipi, ‘antavā loko’tipi, ‘anantavā loko’tipi, ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran’tipi, ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran’tipi, ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi—
segments.en: For example: the world is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are the same thing, or they are different things; after death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist.
The Buddha does not give me a straight answer on these points.

segments.pli: Yāni me bhagavā na byākaroti taṃ me na ruccati, taṃ me nakkhamati.
segments.en: I don’t like that, and do not accept it.
I’ll go to him and ask him about this.
If he gives me a straight answer on any of these points,

segments.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā—

segments.en: I will live the spiritual life under him.
If he does not give me a straight answer on any of these points,

segments.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā—

segments.en: I will reject the training and return to a lesser life.”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mālukyaputto sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā mālukyaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then in the late afternoon, Māluṅkya came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and told the Buddha of his thoughts. He then continued:

segments.pli: “Idha mayhaṃ, bhante, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi—
yānimāni diṭṭhigatāni bhagavatā abyākatāni ṭhapitāni paṭikkhittāni:
‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi—
Yāni me bhagavā na byākaroti taṃ me na ruccati, taṃ me nakkhamati.
‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā—
‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā—

segments.en: “If the Buddha knows
that the world is eternal, please tell me.
If you know
that the world is not eternal, tell me.
If you don’t know

segments.pli: ‘sassato loko’ti vā, ‘asassato loko’ti vā, ajānato kho pana apassato etadeva ujukaṃ hoti yadidaṃ:
segments.en: whether the world is eternal or not, then it is straightforward to simply say:
‘I neither know nor see.’
If you know

that the world is finite, or infinite; that the soul and the body are the same thing, or they are different things; that after death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist, please tell me.

segments.pli: ‘antavā loko’ti vā, ‘anantavā loko’ti vā, ajānato kho pana apassato etadeva ujukaṃ hoti yadidaṃ:
‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran’ti, ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran’ti me bhagavā byākarotu;
‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran’ti, ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran’ti me bhagavā byākarotu.
‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran’ti vā, ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran’ti vā, ajānato kho pana apassato etadeva ujukaṃ hoti yadidaṃ:
‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti me bhagavā byākarotu;
‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti me bhagavā byākarotu.
‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ajānato kho pana apassato etadeva ujukaṃ hoti yadidaṃ:
‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti me bhagavā byākarotu;
‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti me bhagavā byākarotu.

segments.en: If you don’t know

segments.pli: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ajānato kho pana apassato etadeva ujukaṃ hoti yadidaṃ:
segments.en: any of these things, then it is straightforward to simply say:
‘I neither know nor see.’”
“What, Māluṅkyaputta, did I ever say to you:

segments.pli: ‘ehi tvaṃ, mālukyaputta, mayi brahmacariyaṃ cara, ahaṃ te byākarissāmi:
segments.en: ‘Come, Māluṅkyaputta, live the spiritual life under me, and I will declare these things to you’?”

segments.pli: “sassato loko”ti vā, “asassato loko”ti vā, “antavā loko”ti vā, “anantavā loko”ti vā, “taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran”ti vā, “aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran”ti vā, “hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā, “na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā, “hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā, “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā’”ti?

segments.en: “No, sir.”
“Or did you ever say to me:

segments.pli: ‘ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ carissāmi, bhagavā me byākarissati:
segments.en: ‘Sir, I will live the spiritual life under the Buddha, and the Buddha will declare these things to me’?”

segments.pli: “sassato loko”ti vā, “asassato loko”ti vā, “antavā loko”ti vā, “anantavā loko”ti vā, “taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran”ti vā, “aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran”ti vā, “hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā, “na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā, “hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā, “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā’”ti?

segments.en: “No, sir.”
“So it seems that I did not say to you:

segments.pli: ‘ehi tvaṃ, mālukyaputta, mayi brahmacariyaṃ cara, ahaṃ te byākarissāmi:
segments.en: ‘Come, Māluṅkyaputta, live the spiritual life under me, and I will declare these things to you.’

segments.pli: “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā”’ti;

segments.en: And you never said to me:

segments.pli: ‘ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ carissāmi, bhagavā me byākarissati:
segments.en: ‘Sir, I will live the spiritual life under the Buddha, and the Buddha will declare these things to me.’

segments.pli: “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā’ti.
Evaṃ sante, moghapurisa, ko santo kaṃ paccācikkhasi?
segments.en: In that case, you silly man, are you really in a position to be abandoning anything?
Suppose someone were to say this:

segments.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ carissāmi yāva me bhagavā na byākarissati:
segments.en: ‘I will not live the spiritual life under the Buddha until the Buddha declares to me
that the world is eternal, or that the world is not eternal …

segments.pli: “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā’ti,
segments.en: or that after death a Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist.’

segments.pli: abyākatameva taṃ, mālukyaputta, tathāgatena assa, atha so puggalo kālaṃ kareyya.
segments.en: That would still remain undeclared by the Realized One, and meanwhile that person would die.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, mālukyaputta, puriso sallena viddho assa savisena gāḷhapalepanena.
segments.en: Suppose a man was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison.

segments.pli: Tassa mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā bhisakkaṃ sallakattaṃ upaṭṭhapeyyuṃ.
segments.en: His friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a field surgeon to treat him.
But the man would say:

segments.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ purisaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, khattiyo vā brāhmaṇo vā vesso vā suddo vā’ti;
segments.en: ‘I won’t pull out this arrow as long as I don’t know whether the man who wounded me was an aristocrat, a brahmin, a merchant, or a worker.’
He’d say:

segments.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ purisaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto iti vā’ti;
segments.en: ‘I won’t pull out this arrow as long as I don’t know the following things about the man who wounded me: his name and clan;

segments.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ purisaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, dīgho vā rasso vā majjhimo vā’ti;
segments.en: whether he’s tall, short, or medium;

segments.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ purisaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, kāḷo vā sāmo vā maṅguracchavī vā’ti;
segments.en: whether his skin is black, brown, or tawny;

segments.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ purisaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, amukasmiṃ gāme vā nigame vā nagare vā’ti;
segments.en: and what village, town, or city he comes from.

segments.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ dhanuṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, yadi vā cāpo yadi vā kodaṇḍo’ti;
segments.en: I won’t pull out this arrow as long as I don’t know whether the bow that wounded me is made of wood or cane;

segments.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ jiyaṃ jānāmi yāyamhi viddho, yadi vā akkassa yadi vā saṇhassa yadi vā nhārussa yadi vā maruvāya yadi vā khīrapaṇṇino’ti;
segments.en: whether the bow-string is made of swallow-wort fibre, sunn hemp fibre, sinew, sanseveria fibre, or spurge fibre;

segments.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ kaṇḍaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, yadi vā gacchaṃ yadi vā ropiman’ti;
segments.en: whether the shaft is made from a bush or a plantation tree;

segments.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ kaṇḍaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, yassa pattehi vājitaṃ yadi vā gijjhassa yadi vā kaṅkassa yadi vā kulalassa yadi vā morassa yadi vā sithilahanuno’ti;
segments.en: whether the shaft was fitted with feathers from a vulture, a heron, a hawk, a peacock, or a stork;

segments.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ kaṇḍaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, yassa nhārunā parikkhittaṃ yadi vā gavassa yadi vā mahiṃsassa yadi vā bheravassa yadi vā semhārassā’ti;
segments.en: whether the shaft was bound with sinews of a cow, a buffalo, a swamp deer, or a gibbon;

segments.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ sallaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, yadi vā sallaṃ yadi vā khurappaṃ yadi vā vekaṇḍaṃ yadi vā nārācaṃ yadi vā vacchadantaṃ yadi vā karavīrapattan’ti—
segments.en: and whether the arrowhead was spiked, razor-tipped, barbed, made of iron or a calf’s tooth, or lancet-shaped.’

segments.pli: aññātameva taṃ, mālukyaputta, tena purisena assa, atha so puriso kālaṃ kareyya.
segments.en: That man would still not have learned these things, and meanwhile they’d die.

segments.pli: Evameva kho, mālukyaputta, yo evaṃ vadeyya:
segments.en: In the same way, suppose someone was to say:

segments.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ carissāmi yāva me bhagavā na byākarissati:
segments.en: ‘I will not live the spiritual life under the Buddha until the Buddha declares to me
that the world is eternal, or that the world is not eternal …

segments.pli: “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā’ti—
segments.en: or that after death a Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist.’

segments.pli: abyākatameva taṃ, mālukyaputta, tathāgatena assa, atha so puggalo kālaṃ kareyya.
segments.en: That would still remain undeclared by the Realized One, and meanwhile that person would die.

segments.pli: ‘Sassato loko’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evaṃ no.
segments.en: It’s not true that if there were the view ‘the world is eternal’ there would be the living of the spiritual life.

segments.pli: ‘Asassato loko’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evampi no.
segments.en: It’s not true that if there were the view ‘the world is not eternal’ there would be the living of the spiritual life.

segments.pli: ‘Sassato loko’ti vā, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati, ‘asassato loko’ti vā diṭṭhiyā sati attheva jāti, atthi jarā, atthi maraṇaṃ, santi sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā;
segments.en: When there is the view that the world is eternal or that the world is not eternal, there is rebirth, there is old age, there is death, and there is sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
And it is the defeat of these things in this very life that I advocate.

segments.pli: ‘Antavā loko’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evaṃ no.
segments.en: It’s not true that if there were the view ‘the world is finite’ …

segments.pli: ‘Anantavā loko’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evampi no.
segments.en: ‘the world is infinite’ …

segments.pli: ‘Antavā loko’ti vā, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati, ‘anantavā loko’ti vā diṭṭhiyā sati attheva jāti, atthi jarā, atthi maraṇaṃ, santi sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā;
‘Taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evaṃ no.
segments.en: ‘the soul and the body are the same thing’ …

segments.pli: ‘Aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evampi no.
segments.en: ‘the soul and the body are different things’ …

segments.pli: ‘Taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran’ti vā, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati, ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran’ti vā diṭṭhiyā sati attheva jāti … pe …
‘Hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evaṃ no.
segments.en: ‘a Realized One exists after death’ …

segments.pli: ‘Na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evampi no.
segments.en: ‘a Realized One doesn’t exist after death’ …

segments.pli: ‘Hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā diṭṭhiyā sati attheva jāti … pe …
‘Hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evaṃ no.
segments.en: ‘a Realized One both exists and doesn’t exist after death’ …

segments.pli: ‘Neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evampi no.
segments.en: ‘a Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death’ there would be the living of the spiritual life.

segments.pli: ‘Hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā diṭṭhiyā sati attheva jāti … pe …
segments.en: When there are any of these views there is rebirth, there is old age, there is death, and there is sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
And it is the defeat of these things in this very life that I advocate.

segments.pli: Tasmātiha, mālukyaputta, abyākatañca me abyākatato dhāretha;
segments.en: So, Māluṅkyaputta, you should remember what I have not declared as undeclared,
and what I have declared as declared.
And what have I not declared?
I have not declared the following: ‘the world is eternal,’
‘the world is not eternal,’
‘the world is finite,’
‘the world is infinite,’
‘the soul and the body are the same thing,’
‘the soul and the body are different things,’
‘a Realized One exists after death,’
‘a Realized One doesn’t exist after death,’

segments.pli: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti—
segments.en: ‘a Realized One both exists and doesn’t exist after death,’

segments.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti—
segments.en: ‘a Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death.’
And why haven’t I declared these things?

segments.pli: Na hetaṃ, mālukyaputta, atthasaṃhitaṃ na ādibrahmacariyakaṃ na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattati.
segments.en: Because they aren’t beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
That’s why I haven’t declared them.
And what have I declared?
I have declared the following: ‘this is suffering,’
‘this is the origin of suffering,’
‘this is the cessation of suffering,’
‘this is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
And why have I declared these things?

segments.pli: Etañhi, mālukyaputta, atthasaṃhitaṃ etaṃ ādibrahmacariyakaṃ nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati.
segments.en: Because they are beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
That’s why I have declared them.

segments.pli: Tasmātiha, mālukyaputta, abyākatañca me abyākatato dhāretha;
segments.en: So, Māluṅkyaputta, you should remember what I have not declared as undeclared,
and what I have declared as declared.”
That is what the Buddha said.

segments.pli: Attamano āyasmā mālukyaputto bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
segments.en: Satisfied, Venerable Māluṅkyaputta was happy with what the Buddha said.

suttaplex.blurb: A monk demands that the Buddha answer his metaphysical questions, or else he will disrobe. The Buddha compares him to a man struck by an arrow, who refuses treatment until he can have all his questions about the arrow and the archer answered.
